awd_titl_txt: CC* Team: Piloting a CI-Enabled Tribal College and University Research Collaboration
awd_abstract_narration:
The American Indian Higher Education Consortium and institutional partners Sitting Bull College, Nueta Hidatsa Sahnish College, United Tribes Technical College Turtle Mountain Community College, Cankdeska Cikana Community College, and North Dakota State University are partnering on this Cyber Team project that establishes the socio-technical foundations of a cyberinfrastructure (CI)-enabled collaboration that will both support current STEM research and education programs and provide the framework for aggressive research program development. The project involves faculty, students and IT staff at the six participating institutions collaborating on CI improvements, IT staff capacity-building, and distributed STEM programming focused on environmental science, eventually including engineering, digital manufacturing and other STEM disciplines.

The project will provide professional development, support, mentoring and collaborative research opportunities for faculty and students at all North Dakota Tribal Colleges and Universities (TCUs). The project will enhance opportunities for economic development and enhance the design and delivery of health, education, and other services developed through CI-enabled basic and applied research. It will serve as a model for engaging TCUs nationally in the adoption of CI resources necessary to support implementation of a significantly broader range of research and education activities, particularly involving collaborations with the larger research community.

The project’s collaborative capacity-building framework implements the connectivist learning model in which networked human and physical resources constitute a complex adaptive system that generates actionable knowledge (both technical and domain-specific) sustainably. The project tests the hypothesis that a connectivist framework can be transformative in building the research and education capacity of small resource challenged institutions and organizations.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Under the CC* Team: Piloting a CI-enabled Tribal Research Collaboration, the American Indian Higher Education Consortium (AIHEC) Cyberinfrastructure (CI) team achieved four discrete goals including (1) provide CI-readiness to the participating North Dakota (ND) Tribal Colleges and Universities (TCUs); (2) foster and facilitate a collaborative community between the Information Technology (IT) staff and STEM faculty at the ND TCUs and North Dakota State University (NDSU); (3) implement a CI-research computing professional and workforce development program; and (4) provide research planning and implementation support to faculty at all participating campuses. Throughout the project the CI Team held virtual meetings with the ND TCUs and NDSU IT staff to identify specific CC*Team projects, coordinate project activities and provide professional development opportunities. Meetings focused on common ND TCU CI challenges and opportunities, such as techniques for faculty engagement, identifying existing on-campus research infrastructure, and technical infrastructure remediation. 

To support the CI-readiness of the ND TCUs the technical members of the CC* Team conducted virtual site-visits to discuss the upgrade priorities and equipment as well as assistance required for network upgrades including to support remote instruction at each ND TCU. Priorities included upgrading and standardizing campus identity management systems, exploring network and server monitoring solutions, VMWare training, internet service provider engagement, and implementing cybersecurity improvements, including updating cybersecurity policies and resources with work plans designed for each campus and NDSU staff providing in-depth virtual review, research or training in these technical areas.  The CC* Team encouraged collaboration between the ND TCUs and North Dakota STAGEnet, the state-wide internet service provider, focusing on a lowered overall cost of internet service as well as access to additional cybersecurity features. 

CI strategic plans were identified as a critical need, thus, the CI Team developed  a CI assessment and strategic planning process, piloted it with Turtle Mountain College, and then expanded it to other TCUs. Towards the end of the project, NDSU and AIHEC technical staff conducted enhanced on-site visits to each ND TCU, assessing work plan progress, identifying additional project objects, and providing a revised work plan. Areas of concentration included Active Directory and federated identity, Microsoft licensing, cybersecurity upgrades and policies, PowerShell, and equipment retirement and renewal. In addition, grant funds were used to support the adoption of Federated Identity technologies with four of the ND TCU campuses adopting Cirrus ID Bridge and one ND TCU selecting an open-source solution for InCommon and eduroam. 

To foster and facilitate a collaborative community between the IT staff and STEM faculty at the ND TCUs and NDSU, the academic members of the CC* Team identified areas of collaboration that could impact all participating campuses. As a result the CC* Team academic members at three of the five ND TCUs implemented student IT helpdesk; faculty from University of North Dakota (UND) engaged students from the ND TCUs in a summer Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU); and 3-D weather stations were deployed. Materials for the 3-D printed weather stations were developed by NDSU to engage ND TCU students in a climate collaborative with specific goals to teach Linux literacy, IoT networking, database access, python scripting, and data visualization to the participating ND TCU students. 

Throughout the project, the CC* Team provided opportunities for professional development to both the technical IT staff and STEM faculty including attending the Northern Tier Network Consortium annual meeting, supporting VMware training through IVOXY, and continued informal professional development through regular team activities and engagement.      

Along with the legacy of preparing the ND TCU campuses for federated identity, the technical members of the CC* Team supported the ND TCU campuses with exposure, understanding and access to a broad set of cyberinfrastructure resources, from connectivity to cybersecurity to academic CI-resources, that built a strong CI-enabled foundation for the research and academic missions of the ND TCUs. In addition, many project activities, such as CI strategic planning, served as pilots and models for advancing cyberinfrastructure within the full Tribal College community as well as for smaller emerging research colleges and universities nationwide through collaborations with Internet2 and other regional research and education organizations.
